I’ve given up my home to become a digital nomad

Since two weeks I don’t have a home city, or a permanent address, and I’m not looking for one. And it feels great!

In January I started a new life, building my second startup and challenging myself to become a digital nomad. Joining Pirate Summit also meant heavy travelling, I’ve been on over 100 flights this year. My friends used to joke I’m probably homeless. Now I actually am.

Most things I now own fits into a cabin-luggage size Muji bag. Photo by Kristaps Berzinskis

Living on a plane, huh? 
I was spending increasingly little time in my ‘home’ in Riga, with 3 days per month in May and June. It became a place to repack my bags. But it still had a sentimental value. A lot of it. It was my home. A place to return. I drew a line from Riga to anywhere I go and back.

“I live on a plane” is an overused phrase. But what if that could actually work? I decided to challenge myself to become a full time digital nomad.

Making the jump 
Getting rid of things was the hardest. First of all I never realised how many things I own. Mostly clothes, some books (and I almost don’t read). Took me a whole day to systematically throw out most of my belongings. Some did have a sentimental value too, and frankly I didn’t feel right about throwing out things that could be useful for others. I tried to give away as much as I could.

If you travel for a month, you may pack a dozen of things to last for all your trip. If you travel indefinitely you don’t really need that many things. The more you bring with you the more likely you won’t actually need them.

Then there’s a social aspect. Our society expect you to have a house, probably a car, and a well-payed job. I’m technically unemployed (as my new startup cannot afford to pay me any salary), now I’m also homeless, never had a car either. I think I may have removed a few things from equation. And yes, a bit scary it is.

If I could only be a little more mobile and hey – now I can live in Riga, Berlin, Tehran or San Francisco.

A nomadic lifestyle

Resting on a mountain slope, Damavand, Iran. Photo by Uldis

I’m not an immigrant, as there is no country of destination for me, I am also not a tourist as I don’t really ‘visit’ places, I live there. Just not too long. My passport lets me live in most countries for a few months a year. That’s more than enough, I don’t need a residency permit in any of them. It’s sort of a way to hack the immigration policies.

I rely on sharing economy, Airbnb, friends and Couchsurfing. Wherever I am I call home. What made us so attached to locations is our friends and family. But what if my closest friends are across many cities and states?

I can work in an office, a co-workig or coffee shop. Or – anywhere where’s internet. Every day I go to work and every day I go home to rest, just every other day it is in a different city. Nontheless, I’m curious if this could work for me. Most digital nomads I know are freelancers, their professional lives are travel-centric. I’m a CEO of an ambitious startup, I have long working hours, my job is to run a team, build a fast growing company and do fundraising. Can I run a company remotely and can it actually work? It is up to my co-founders, board and customers to judge, I guess. One thing I can do is being very open.

Lifestyle with a few perks 
I’ve lived in the busy Shibuya ward by the famous mega-crossing, or a small and slightly abandoned village of Kiyosato, or a two floor loft in an old Nokia factory in Helsinki. Had a dinner in a restaurant in a dusty side street in Zamalek, Cairo. Or spent a day in parks with a good friend in an emerging and exciting suburb of Neukolln in Berlin. I’ve walk the narrow streets of Darabad in Tehran and lived on a private island in Bahrain. I played old computer games with kids in a refugee camp in south of Beirut. Now I’m in Chinatown of San Francisco. I’ve met some of most exciting people I wouldn’t meet if I had stayed in my home town. I made connections that will last, friendships that means so much to me, and gathered stories to be told. Can your home do it?

Property is actually virtual. Let’s say you’d like to live in a house with a swimming pool and 5 bedrooms. How often would you need it all. You can get any house in Airbnb, whenever you need it. Boom, I have a loft with an ocean view for a party with my friends. Or a small room in a suburb when I just want to sleep and be antisocial. I don’t need to own things to enjoy them.

So far I’ve given up basic status symbols of our society. And I feel really good. I probably don’t realise the full consequences of my decision and I will update you over the next months.

So, where did I go? First stop was Tehran. Now I am in San Francisco. Where next? Let’s meet somewhere in the world!
